2.1 Vector Algebra

2.1.1 Vector Operations

Walking 5 km north and then 12 km east, we will have gone a total of 17 km, but we‚Äôre not 13 km from where we set out, which is only 7. We need a set of mathematics principles to describe quantities like this, which evidently do NOT add in the ordinary way.

The reason they don‚Äôt, is displacements have direction as well as magnitude , and it is essential to take both into account when we combine them. Such objects are called vectors .

Examples include: velocity, acceleration, force, momentum ‚Ä¶

By contrast, quantities that have magnitude but no direction are called scalars .

Examples include: mass, charge, density, temperature, ‚Ä¶

We shall use boldface ( A ‚Üí , B ‚Üí , and so on) for vectors and ordinary type for scalars. The magnitude of a vector A ‚Üí is written | A ‚Üí | or, more simply, A . In diagrams, vectors are denoted by arrows: the length of the arrow is proportional to the magnitude of the vector, and the arrow indicates its direction.

Minus A ‚Üí ( ‚àí A ‚Üí ) is a vector with the same magnitude as A ‚Üí but of opposite direction.

Vectors have magnitude and direction but not location .

Here we will define four (4) vector operations: addition and three kinds of multiplication.

Addition of Two Vectors Place the tail of B ‚Üí at the head of A ‚Üí . Their sum, A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí , is the vector from the tail of A ‚Üí to the head of B ‚Üí . Addition is commutative :

A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí = B ‚Üí + A ‚Üí ,

5 kilometers east followed by 12 kilometers north gets us to the same place as 12 kilometers north followed by 5 kilometers east. Addition is also associative :

( A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí ) + C ‚Üí = A ‚Üí + ( B ‚Üí + C ‚Üí ) .

To subtract a vector, add its opposite

A ‚Üí ‚àí B ‚Üí = A ‚Üí + ( ‚àí B ‚Üí ) .

Multiplication by a Scalar Value Multiplication of a vector by a positive scalar a multiplies the magnitude but leaves the direction unchanged . This means if a is negative, the direction is reversed. Scalar multiplication is distributive :

a ( A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí ) = a A ‚Üí + a B ‚Üí .

Dot Product of Two Vectors The dot product of two vectors is defined by:

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ‚â° A B cos ‚Å° ùúÉ (2.1)

where ùúÉ is the angle they form when placed tail-to-tail.

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí is itself a scalar. 1

The dot product is commutative ,
A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí = B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí ,

and distributive ,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( B ‚Üí + C ‚Üí ) = A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí + A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí , (2.2)

Geometrically, A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí is the product of A times the projection of B ‚Üí along A ‚Üí . 2 If the two vectors are parallel, then A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí = A B . In particular, for any vector A ‚Üí ,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí = A 2 (2.3)

If A ‚Üí and B ‚Üí are perpendicular, then A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí = 0 .

Cross Product of Two Vectors The cross product of two (2) vectors is defined by:

A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ‚â° A B sin ‚Å° ùúÉ n ^ (2.4)

where n ^ is a unit vector (vector of magnitude 1) pointing perpendicular to the plane of A ‚Üí and B ‚Üí . Of course, there are two directions perpendicular to any plane: in and out .

The ambiguity is resolved by the right-hand rule : let our fingers point in the direction of the first vector and curl around (via the smaller angle) toward the second; then our thumb indicates the direction of n ^ .

A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí is itself a vector and it is also known as vector product .

The cross product is distributive ,
A ‚Üí √ó ( B ‚Üí + C ‚Üí ) = ( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) + ( A ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) (2.5)

but NOT commutative:

( B ‚Üí √ó A ‚Üí ) = ‚àí ( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) (2.6)

If two (2) vectors are parallel, their cross product is zero. In particular,

A ‚Üí √ó A ‚Üí = 0 ,

for any vector A ‚Üí .

2.1.2 Vector Component Forms

In the previous section, we defined the four (4) vector operations in abstract form, without reference to any particular coordinate system.

In practice, it is often easier to set up Cartesian coordinates ( x , y , z ) and work with vector components . Let x ^ , ≈∑ , ·∫ë be unit vectors parallel to the x , y , and z axes, respectively. An arbitrary vector A ‚Üí can be expanded in terms of these basis vectors :

A ‚Üí = A x x ^ + A y ≈∑ + A z ·∫ë

The symbols A x , A y , A z , are the components of A ‚Üí . In geometrical terms they are the projections of A ‚Üí along the three (3) coordinate axes (i.e., A x = A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ x ^ , A y = A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ≈∑ , A z = A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ·∫ë ).

We can now reformulate each of the four (4) vector operations as a rule for manipulating components:

A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí = ( A x x ^ + A y ≈∑ + A z ·∫ë ) + ( B x x ^ + B y ≈∑ + B z ·∫ë ) = ( A x + B x ) x ^ + ( A y + B y ) ≈∑ + ( A z + B z ) ·∫ë

The operation rules are as follows:

i.
To add vectors, add like components. a A ‚Üí = ( a A x ) x ^ + ( a A y ) ≈∑ + ( a A z ) ·∫ë
ii.
To multiply by a scalar, multiply each component. As x ^ , y ^ , z ^ are mutually perpendicular unit vectors, the following properties are valid:
x ^ ‚ãÖ x ^ = y ^ ‚ãÖ y ^ = z ^ ‚ãÖ z ^ = 1 x ^ ‚ãÖ y ^ = x ^ ‚ãÖ z ^ = y ^ ‚ãÖ z ^ = 0

Accordingly,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí = ( A x x ^ + A y y ^ + A z z ^ ) ‚ãÖ ( B x x ^ + B y y ^ + B z z ^ )
iii.
To calculate the dot product, multiply like components, and add. In particular,
A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí = A x 2 + A y 2 + A z 2 , so A = A x 2 + A y 2 + A z 2

Similarly the following relations can be derived:

x ^ √ó x ^ = y ^ √ó y ^ = z ^ √ó z ^ = 0 , x ^ √ó y ^ = ‚àí y ^ √ó x ^ = z ^ , y ^ √ó z ^ = ‚àí z ^ √ó y ^ = x ^ , z ^ √ó x ^ = ‚àí x ^ √ó z ^ = y ^ .

Therefore,

A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí = ( A x x ^ + A y y ^ + A z z ^ ) √ó ( B x x ^ + B y y ^ + B z z ^ ) = ( A y B z ‚àí A z B y ) x ^ + ( A z B x ‚àí A x B z ) y ^ + ( A x B y ‚àí A y B x ) z ^ .

This expression look unruly but we can tidy it up and write it more neatly as a determinant :

A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí = | x ^ y ^ z ^ A x A y A z B x B y B z | (2.7)

iv.
To calculate the cross product, form the determinant whose first row is x ^ , y ^ , z ^ , whose second row is A ‚Üí (in component form), and whose third row is B ‚Üí .

2.1.3 Triple Products

As the cross product of two (2) vectors is itself a vector, it can be dotted or crossed with a 3 rd vector to form a triple product.

Scalar Triple Product Evidently,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( B ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) = B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( C ‚Üí √ó A ‚Üí ) = C ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) ,

for they all correspond to the same value.

The alphabetical order is preserved.

Alternatively, the non-alphabetical triple products,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( C ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) = B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( A ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) = C ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( B ‚Üí √ó A ‚Üí ) ,

have the opposite sign. In component form,

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( B ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) = | A x A y A z B x B y B z C x C y C z | .

A final point worth mentioning is the dot and cross can be interchanged:

A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( B ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) = ( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí ,

however, it is important to stress it out, the placement of the parentheses is critical :

Information : Cross Product of Two Scalars

( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ) √ó C ‚Üí is a meaningless expression. We can‚Äôt make a cross product from a scalar and a vector.

Vector Triple Product The vector triple product can be simplified by the BAC-CAB rule:

A ‚Üí √ó ( B ‚Üí √ó C ‚Üí ) = B ‚Üí ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí ) ‚àí C ‚Üí ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ) .

Please observe that the following triple product

( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) √ó C ‚Üí = ‚àí C ‚Üí √ó ( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) = ‚àí A ‚Üí ( B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí ) + B ‚Üí ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí )

is an entirely different vector. 3 All higher vector products can be similarly reduced, often by repeated application, so it is never necessary for an expression to contain more than one cross product in any term. For instance,

( A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ ( C ‚Üí √ó D ‚Üí ) = ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí ) ( B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ D ‚Üí ) ‚àí ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ D ‚Üí ) ( B ‚Üí ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí ) , A ‚Üí √ó [ B ‚Üí √ó ( C ‚Üí √ó D ‚Üí ) ] = B ‚Üí [ A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( C ‚Üí √ó D ‚Üí ) ] ‚àí ( A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ) ( C ‚Üí √ó D ‚Üí ) .

2.1.4 Position, Displacement, and Separation Vectors

The location of a point in three dimensions can be described by listing its Cartesian coordinates ( x , y , z ) . The vector to that point from the origin ( O ) is called the position vector :

r ‚Üí ‚â° x x ^ + y y ^ + z z ^

Throughout this course, r ‚Üí will be used to measure distance . Its magnitude:

r = x 2 + y 2 + z 2

is the distance from the origin, and

r ^ = r ‚Üí r = ( x ) x ^ + ( y ) ≈∑ + ( z ) ·∫ë x 2 + y 2 + z 2

is a unit vector pointing radially outward . The infinitesimal displacement vector , from ( x , y , z ) to ( x + d x , y + d y , z + d z ) , is

d l ‚Üí = ( d x ) x ^ + ( d y ) ≈∑ + ( d z ) ·∫ë .

In electrodynamics, one frequently encounters problems involving two (2) points:

source point

( r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤ ), where an electric charge is located

field point

( r ‚Üí ), at which we are calculating the electric or magnetic field

To make these redundant calculations easier to handle, let‚Äôs use the following short-hand notation:

r ‚â° r ‚Üí ‚àí r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤

Its magnitude is:

r = | r ‚Üí ‚àí r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤ |

and a unit vector in the direction from r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤ to r ‚Üí is

r ^ = r ^ r = r ‚Üí ‚àí r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤ | r ‚Üí ‚àí r ‚Üí ‚Ä≤ |

In Cartesian coordinates our new short-notations would be as following:

r = ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) ≈∑ + ( z ‚àí z ‚Ä≤ ) ·∫ë r = ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( z ‚àí z ‚Ä≤ ) 2 r ^ = ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) ≈∑ + ( z ‚àí z ‚Ä≤ ) ·∫ë ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( z ‚àí z ‚Ä≤ ) 2

2.2 Differential Calculus

2.2.1 Ordinary Derivatives

Assume a function of just one (1) variable: f ( x ) . Therefore, the question we need to answer is what does the derivative, d f ‚àï d x , do?

It tells us how rapidly the function f ( x ) varies when we change the argument x by an infinitesimal amount, d x :

d f = ( d f d t ) d x

If we increment x by an infinitesimal amount d x , then f changes by an amount d f . 4

Geometrically, the derivative d f ‚àï d t is the slope of the graph of f versus x .

2.2.2 Gradient

Assume a function which accepts three (3) variables. As an example, lets take the temperature T ( x , y , z ) in the lecture room. Start out in one corner, and set up a system of cardinal directions. Then for each point ( x , y , z ) in the room, T gives the temperature at that spot. We want to generalise the notion of derivative to functions like T , which depend NOT on one but on three variables.

A derivative tells us how fast the function varies , if we move a little distance. But this time the situation is more complicated, because it depends on what direction we move:

  • Going straight up, the temperature will probably increase fairly rapidly,

  • Moving horizontally, it may not change much at all.

In fact, the question of ‚ÄúHow fast does T vary?‚Äù can have an infinite number of answers, one for each direction we might choose to explore. Fortunately, the problem is not as bad as it looks. A theorem on partial derivatives states:

d T = ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ x ) d x + ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ y ) d y + ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ z ) d z

This tells us how T changes when we alter all three (3) variables by the infinitesimal amounts of d x , d y , d z . We can write the aforementioned equation as a dot product:

d T = ( d T d x x ^ + d T d y ≈∑ + d T d z ·∫ë ) ‚ãÖ ( ( d x ) x ^ + ( d y ) ≈∑ + ( d z ) ·∫ë ) = ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ ( d l ‚Üí ) ,

where

‚àá ‚Å° T ‚â° d T d x x ^ + d T d y ≈∑ + d T d z ·∫ë

is the gradient of T . Note that ‚àá ‚Å° T is a vector quantity , with three (3) components. 5

2.2.3 The Del Operator

The gradient has the formal appearance of a vector, ( ‚àá ‚Å° ). 6 multiplying a scalar T :

‚àá ‚Å° T = ( x ^ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ x + ≈∑ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y + ·∫ë ‚àÇ ‚àÇ z ) T

The term in parentheses is called del operator:

‚àá ‚Å° = x ^ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ x + ≈∑ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y + ≈∑ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ z (2.8)

Del is NOT a vector, in the usual sense. It doesn‚Äôt mean much until we provide it with a function to act upon. Furthermore, it does NOT ‚Äúmultiply‚Äù T . Rather, it is an instruction to differentiate what follows. To be precise, then, we say that ‚àá ‚Å° is a vector operator which acts upon T , not a vector that multiplies T .

With this qualification, though, ‚àá ‚Å° mimics the behaviour of an ordinary vector in virtually every way. Almost anything that can be done with other vectors can also be done with ‚àá ‚Å° . Now, an ordinary vector A ‚Üí can multiply in three (3) ways:

1.
By a scalar a : A ‚Üí a ;
2.
By a vector B ‚Üí , via the dot product: A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ;
3.
By a vector B ‚Üí via the cross product: A ‚Üí √ó B ‚Üí .

Correspondingly, there are three ways the operator ‚àá ‚Å° can act:

1.
On a scalar function T : ‚àá ‚Å° T (the gradient);
2.
On a vector function v ‚Üí , via the dot product: ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí (divergence)
3.
On a vector function v ‚Üí , via the cross product: ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí (curl).

It is time to examine the other two (2) vector derivatives: divergence and curl.

Divergence

From the definition of ‚àá ‚Å° we construct the divergence as follows:

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí = ( ( ‚àÇ ‚àÇ x ) x ^ + ( ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y ) ≈∑ + ( ‚àÇ ‚àÇ z ) ·∫ë ) ‚ãÖ ( ( v x ) x ^ + ( v y ) ≈∑ + ( v z ) ·∫ë ) = ‚àÇ v x ‚àÇ x + ‚àÇ v y ‚àÇ y + ‚àÇ v z ‚àÇ z .

Observe that the divergence of a vector function v ‚Üí is itself a scalar ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí .

Let‚Äôs try to visualise this concept. The name divergence is well chosen, for ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí is a measure of how much v ‚Üí spreads out 7 from the initial point.

For example, a vector function in Fig. 2.4 has a large (positive) divergence. 8 two functions in Fig. 2.4 has zero divergence, and one function has a negative divergence.

As an example, imagine standing at the edge of a pond. Sprinkle some sawdust on the surface.

1.
If the material spreads out, then we dropped it at a point of positive divergence;
2.
If it collects together, we dropped it at a point of negative divergence.

Curl From the definition of ‚àá ‚Å° we construct the curl:

V √ó v = | x ^ y ^ z ^ ‚àÇ ‚àï ‚àÇ x ‚àÇ ‚àï ‚àÇ y ‚àÇ ‚àï ‚àÇ z v x v y v z | = x ^ ( ‚àÇ v z ‚àÇ y ‚àí ‚àÇ v y ‚àÇ z ) + y ^ ( ‚àÇ v x ‚àÇ z ‚àí ‚àÇ v z ‚àÇ x ) + z ^ ( ‚àÇ v y ‚àÇ x ‚àí ‚àÇ v x ‚àÇ y ) .

As with divergence, the name curl is also well chosen, for ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí is a measure of how much v ‚Üí swirls around the point in question. Therefore the functions in Fig. 1.18 all have zero curl, whereas the functions in Fig. 2.5 all have a substantial curl sans one, pointing in the ·∫ë direction, as the natural right-hand rule would suggest.

To finish these two (2) important operations, let‚Äôs again imagine we are standing at the edge of a pond. Float a small flower, if it starts to rotate, then we placed it at a point of nonzero curl. A whirlpool would be a region of large curl.

2.2.4 Product Rules

The calculation of ordinary derivatives is facilitated by a number of rules which are as follows:

Similar relations hold for the vector derivatives. Thus,

‚àá ‚Å° ( f + g ) = ‚àá ‚Å° f + ‚àá ‚Å° g , ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí ) = ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí ) + ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ B ‚Üí ) , ‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( A ‚Üí + B ‚Üí ) = ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó A ‚Üí ) + ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó B ‚Üí ) ,

and

‚àá ‚Å° ( k f ) = k ‚àá ‚Å° f , ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( k A ) = k ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ A ) , ‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( k A ) = k ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó A ) , (2.9)

The product rules, on the other hand, are not quite so simple. There are two (2) ways to construct a scalar as the product of two functions:

f g (product¬†of¬†two¬†scalar¬†functions) , A ‚ãÖ B (dot¬†product¬†of¬†two¬†vector¬†functions) ,

and two ways to make a vector:

f A (scalar¬†times¬†vector), A √ó B (cross¬†product¬†of¬†two¬†vectors).

Accordingly, there are six (6) product rules, which are given in Tbl. 2.2 .

The proofs for rules given in Tbl. 2.2 come straight from the product rule for ordinary derivatives. As an example:

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( f A ‚Üí ) = ‚àÇ ‚àÇ x ( f A x ) + ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y ( f A y ) + ‚àÇ ‚àÇ z ( f A z ) = ( ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ x A x + f ‚àÇ A x ‚àÇ x ) + ( ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ y A y + f ‚àÇ A y ‚àÇ y ) + ( ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ z A z + f ‚àÇ A z ‚àÇ z ) = ( ‚àá ‚Å° f ) ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí + f ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí ) .

It is also possible to formulate three quotient rules:

‚àá ‚Å° ( f g ) = g ‚àá ‚Å° f ‚àí f ‚àá ‚Å° g g 2 , ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( A ‚Üí g ) = g ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ A ‚Üí ) ‚àí A ‚Üí ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá ‚Å° g ) g 2 , ‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( A ‚Üí g ) = g ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó A ‚Üí ) + A ‚Üí √ó ( ‚àá ‚Å° g ) g 2 .

However, given these can be obtained quickly from the previously mentioned product rules, there is no point in listing them separately and is left for the reader as exercise.

2.2.5 Second Derivatives

The gradient, the divergence, and the curl are the only first derivatives we can make with ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí by applying ‚àá ‚Å° twice, we can construct five (5) types of 2 nd derivatives.

The gradient ‚àá ‚Å° T is a vector, so we can take the divergence and curl of it:

1.
Divergence of gradient: ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) .
2.
Curl of gradient: ‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) .

The divergence ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí is a scalar, therefore all we can do is take its gradient:

3.
Gradient of divergence: ‚àá ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí ) .

The curl ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí is a vector, so we can take its divergence and curl:

4.
Divergence of curl: ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) .
5.
Curl of curl: ‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) .

This exhausts the possible combinations, and in fact NOT all of them give anything new. Let‚Äôs consider them one at a time:

Divergence of a Gradient

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) = ( x ^ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ x + ≈∑ ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y + ·∫ë ‚àÇ ‚àÇ z ) ‚ãÖ ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ x x ^ + ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ y ≈∑ + ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ z ·∫ë ) = ‚àÇ 2 T ‚àÇ x 2 + ‚àÇ 2 T ‚àÇ y 2 + ‚àÇ 2 T ‚àÇ z 2 . This object, which we write as ‚àá ‚Å° 2 T for short, is called the Laplacian 9 of T , which will be our focus later.

The Laplacian of a scalar T is a scalar value.

Occasionally, we will use the Laplacian of a vector, ‚àá ‚Å° 2 v ‚Üí . By this we mean a vector quantity whose x -component is the Laplacian of v x , and so on.
‚àá ‚Å° 2 v ‚Üí ‚â° ( ‚àá ‚Å° 2 v x ) x ^ + ( ‚àá ‚Å° 2 v y ) ≈∑ + ( ‚àá ‚Å° 2 v z ) ·∫ë

This is nothing more than a convenient extension of the meaning of ‚àá ‚Å° 2 .

Curl of a Gradient

The curl of a gradient is always zero:

‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( ‚àá ‚Å° T )

This is an important fact , which will be used repeatedly. Without going into too much detail into the proof, it relies on the following relation:

‚àÇ ‚àÇ x ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ y ) = ‚àÇ ‚àÇ y ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ x )
Gradient of Divergence

This operation rarely occurs in physical applications, and it has not been given any special name of its own. Notice that ‚àá ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí ) is NOT the same as the Laplacian of a vector:

‚àá ‚Å° 2 = ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ‚àá ‚Å° ) ‚â† ‚àá ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí )

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) = 0 .
Curl of a Curl

As we can check from the definition of ‚àá ‚Å° :

‚àá ‚Å° √ó ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) = ‚àá ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí ) ‚àí ‚àá ‚Å° 2 v ‚Üí . (2.10)

So curl-of-curl gives nothing new as the first term is just the divergence of a curl, and the second is the Laplacian. To put it short, then, there are just two kinds of second derivatives: 10

1.
Laplacian,
2.
Gradient of divergence.

2.3 Integral Calculus

2.3.1 Line, Surface, and Volume Integrals

In electrodynamics, we encounter several different kinds of integrals, among which the most important are line (or path ) integrals , surface integrals (or flux ), and volume integrals , which will be the focus of this section.

Line Integrals Has an expression of the form:

‚à´ a b v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí

where v ‚Üí is a vector function, d l ‚Üí is the infinitesimal displacement vector, and the integral is to be carried out along a prescribed path P from point a to point b . If the path forms a closed loop. 11

We put a circle on the integral sign:

‚àÆ v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí

At each point on the path, we take the dot product of v ‚Üí (evaluated at that point) with the displacement d l ‚Üí to the next point on the path.

A good example of a line integral is the work done by a force F ‚Üí :

W = ‚à´ F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí

Ordinarily, the value of a line integral depends critically on the path taken from a ‚Üí to b ‚Üí , but there is an important special class of vector functions for which the line integral is independent of path and is determined entirely by the end points.

It will be our business in due course to characterise this special class of vectors.

A force which has this property is called conservative .

Surface Integrals

A surface integral is an expression of the form:
‚à´ S v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí

where v ‚Üí is a vector function, and the integral is over a specified surface S . Here d a is an infinitesimal patch of area, with direction perpendicular to the surface . There are, two (2) directions perpendicular to any surface, so the sign of a surface integral is intrinsically ambiguous.

If the surface is closed. 12 we put a circle on the integral sign:

‚àÆ v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí

Tradition dictates that outward is positive, but for open surfaces it‚Äôs arbitrary.

As an example, if v ‚Üí describes the flow of a fluid. 13 then ‚à´ v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí represents the total mass per unit time passing through the surface.

Ordinarily, the value of a surface integral depends on the particular surface chosen, but there is a special class of vector functions for which it is independent of the surface and is determined entirely by the boundary line. An important task will be to characterise this special class of functions.

Volume Integrals A volume integral is an expression of the form:

‚à´ V T d œÑ

where T is a scalar function and d œÑ is an infinitesimal volume element. In Cartesian coordinates,

d œÑ = d x d y d z

As an example, if T is the density of a substance. 14 then the volume integral would give the total mass.

Occasionally we shall encounter volume integrals of vector functions:

‚à´ v ‚Üí d œÑ = ‚à´ ( v x x ^ + v y ≈∑ + v z ·∫ë ) d œÑ = x ^ ‚à´ v x d œÑ + ≈∑ ‚à´ v y d œÑ + ·∫ë ‚à´ v z d œÑ .

As the unit vectors ( x ^ , ≈∑ , ·∫ë ) are constants, they can be taken outside the integral.

2.3.2 The Fundamental Theorems of Vector Calculus

Assume f ( x ) is a function of one (1) variable. Based on this, the fundamental theorem of calculus says:

Theory 2.2: Calculus Theorem

The integral of a derivative over some region is given by the value of the function at the end points (boundaries)

‚à´ a b ( d f d x ) d x = f ( x ) ‚àí f ( a ) or ‚à´ a b F ( x ) d x = f ( x ) ‚àí f ( a )

In vector calculus there are three (3) species of derivative 15 and each has its own ‚Äúfundamental theorem‚Äù with essentially the same format. Our purpose here is to not prove these theorems here, but rather, understand what they mean .

The Fundamental Theorem for Gradients Suppose we have a scalar function of three (3) variables T ( x , y , z ) . Starting at point a , move a small distance d l ‚Üí 1 . The function T will change by an amount:

d T = ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí 1

Now let‚Äôs move an additional small displacement d l ‚Üí 2 . The incremental change in T will be now:

d T = ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí 2

In this manner, proceeding by infinitesimal steps, we make the journey to point b ‚Üí . At each step we compute the gradient of T , at that point, and dot it into the displacement d l ‚Üí ‚Ä¶this gives us the change in T .

Theory 2.4: Gradient Theorem

The total change in T in going from a ‚Üí to b ‚Üí (along the path selected) is:

‚à´ a ‚Üí b ‚Üí ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí = T ( b ‚Üí ) ‚àí T ( a ‚Üí )

Similar to ‚Äúordinary‚Äù fundamental theorem, this theorem says the integral 16 of a derivative, which here the gradient, is given by the value of the function at the boundaries which are a ‚Üí and b ‚Üí respectively.

As an example, assume we want to measure the height of GrossGlockner. We could climb the mountain from base, or take the high alpine road, or take a helicopter ride all the way up to top. Regardless or the options we take, we should get the same answer either way. 17

Theory 2.6: Line Independence of Gradient

Gradients have the special property that their line integrals are path independent:

  • ‚à´ a ‚Üí b ‚Üí ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí is independent of the path taken from a ‚Üí to b ‚Üí .

  • ‚àÆ ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° T ) ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí = 0 , since the beginning and end points are identical, and hence T ( b ‚Üí ) ‚àí T ( a ‚Üí ) = 0 .

The Fundamental Theorem for Divergences

This theorem has at least three (3) special names:

1.
Gauss‚Äôs theorem,
2.
Green‚Äôs theorem,
3.
Divergence theorem.

The fundamental theorem for divergences states:

Theory 2.8: Divergence Theorem

the integral of a derivative (the divergence ) over a region (in this case the volume , V ) is equal to the value of the function at the boundary (in this case the surface S bounding the volume).

‚à´ V ( ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí ) d œÑ = ‚àÆ S v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí .

The boundary term is itself an integral, more specifically, a surface integral. This is reasonable: the ‚Äúboundary‚Äù of a line is just two end points, but the boundary of a volume is a closed surface. To create an analogy, if v ‚Üí represents the flow of an incompressible fluid, then the flux v ‚Üí is the total amount of fluid passing out through the surface, per unit time. Now, the divergence measures the spreading out of the vectors from a point, a place of high divergence is like a tap, pouring out liquid. If we have a bunch of tap in a region filled with incompressible fluid, an equal amount of liquid will be forced out through the boundaries of the region. In fact, there are two (2) ways we could determine how much is being produced:

i.
we could count up all the faucets, recording how much each puts out
ii.
we could go around the boundary, measuring the flow at each point, and add it all up

We get the same answer either way:

‚à´ (faucets¬†within¬†the¬†volume) = ‚àÆ (flow¬†out¬†through¬†the¬†surface)

Exercise 2.16: An Example of Divergence Theorem

( F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ n ^ ) d a = x 2 + y 2 + z 2 a d a = a 2 a d a = a d a .

2.3.3 The Fundamental Theorem for Curls

The fundamental theorem for curls, also known as Stokes‚Äô theorem , states: 18

Theory 2.10: Stokes‚Äô Theorem

Integral of a derivative over a region ( S ) is equal to the value of the function at boundary ( P ).

‚à´ S ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí = ‚àÆ P v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí .

Similar to the divergence theorem, the boundary term is itself an integral. Specifically, a closed line integral .

Remember the curl measures the twist of the vectors v ‚Üí . Think of a region of high curl as a whirlpool, where if we put a wheel there, it will rotate. Now, the integral of the curl over some surface (or, more precisely, the flux of the curl through the surface) represents the total amount of swirl , and we can determine that just as well by going around the edge and finding how much the flow is following the boundary.

‚àÆ ‚Å° v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí is sometimes called the circulation of v ‚Üí .

There seems to be an ambiguity in Stokes‚Äô theorem: concerning the boundary line integral:

Which way are we supposed to go around? 19

The answer is that it doesn‚Äôt matter which way we go as long as we are consistent , for there is an additional sign ambiguity in the surface integral:

Which way does d a ‚Üí point?

For a closed surface. 20 d a ‚Üí points in the direction of the outward normal. But for an open surface, which way would be defined as out? Consistency in Stokes‚Äô theorem is given by the right-hand rule. If our rings point in the direction of the line integral, then our thumb fixes the direction of d a ‚Üí .

Ordinary, a flux integral depends critically on what surface we integrate over, but this is NOT the case with curls. For Stokes‚Äô theorem says that ‚à´ ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí is equal to the line integral of v ‚Üí around the boundary, and the latter makes no reference to the specific surface we choose.

Preposition I

‚à´ ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí depends only on the boundary line, not on the particular surface used.

Preposition II

‚àÆ ‚Å° ( ‚àá ‚Å° √ó v ‚Üí ) ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí = 0 for any closed surface.

2.4 Curvilinear Coordinates

2.4.1 Spherical Coordinate System

It is possible to label a point P in Cartesian coordinates ( x , y , z ) , but sometimes it is more convenient to use spherical coordinates ( r , ùúÉ , œï ) ; r is the distance from the origin, ùúÉ is called the polar angle , and œï is the azimuthal angle . Their relation to Cartesian coordinates can be read from Fig. 2.10 a.

x = r sin ‚Å° ùúÉ cos ‚Å° œï , y = r sin ‚Å° ùúÉ sin ‚Å° œï , z = r cos ‚Å° ùúÉ .

Fig. 2.10 a also shows three unit vectors, r ^ , ùúÉ ^ , œï ^ , pointing in the direction of increase of the corresponding coordinates.

They constitute an orthogonal basis set. 21 similar to x ^ , ≈∑ , ·∫ë , and any vector A ‚Üí can be expressed in terms of them, in the usual way:

A ‚Üí = ( A r ) r ^ + ( A ùúÉ ) ùúÉ ^ + ( A œï ) œï ^

Here, A r , A ùúÉ , A œï are the radial, polar, and azimuthal components of vector A ‚Üí . In terms of the Cartesian unit vectors:

r ^ = ( sin ‚Å° ùúÉ cos ‚Å° œï ) r ^ + ( sin ‚Å° ùúÉ sin ‚Å° œï ) ùúÉ ^ + ( cos ‚Å° ùúÉ ) œï ^ , ùúÉ ^ = ( cos ‚Å° ùúÉ cos ‚Å° œï ) r ^ + ( cos ‚Å° ùúÉ sin ‚Å° œï ) ùúÉ ^ + ( ‚àí sin ‚Å° ùúÉ ) œï ^ , œï ^ = ( ‚àí sin ‚Å° œï ) r ^ + ( cos ‚Å° œï ) ùúÉ ^ + ( 0 ) œï ^ .

An infinitesimal displacement in the r ^ direction is simply d r , just as an infinitesimal element of length in the x ^ direction is d x :

d l r = d r

On the other hand, an infinitesimal element of length in the ùúÉ ^ direction is NOT just d ùúÉ but rather,

d l ùúÉ = r d ùúÉ

Similarly, an infinitesimal element of length in the œï ^ direction is

d l œï = r sin ‚Å° ùúÉ d œï

Thus the general infinitesimal displacement d l ‚Üí is:

d l ‚Üí = ( d r ) r ^ + ( r d ùúÉ ) ùúÉ ^ + ( r sin ‚Å° ùúÉ ) œï ^

This plays the role d l ‚Üí = ( d x ) x ^ + ( d y ) ≈∑ + ( d z ) ·∫ë plays in Cartesian coordinates. The infinitesimal volume element d œÑ , in spherical coordinates, is the product of the three (3) infinitesimal displacements:

d œÑ = d l r d l ùúÉ d l œï = r 2 sin ‚Å° ùúÉ d r d ùúÉ d œï .

It is not possible to give a general expression for surface elements d a ‚Üí , since these depend on the orientation of the surface. We simply have to analyse the geometry for any given case, which goes for Cartesian and curvilinear coordinates.

Integrating over the surface of a sphere, for instance, makes r constant, whereas ùúÉ and œï change:
d a ‚Üí 1 = d l ùúÉ d l œï r ^ = r 2 sin ‚Å° ùúÉ d ùúÉ d œï r ^

On the other hand, if the surface lies in the x y plane, making ùúÉ is constant, while r and œï vary:

d a ‚Üí 2 = d l r d l œï ùúÉ ^ = r d r d œï ùúÉ ^

Finally: r ranges from 0 to ‚àû , œï from 0 to 2 œÄ , and ùúÉ from 0 to œÄ .

≈ù = cos ‚Å° œï x ^ + sin ‚Å° œï ≈∑ œï ^ = ‚àí sin ‚Å° œï x ^ + cos ‚Å° œï ≈∑ ·∫ë = ·∫ë

2.5 Dirac Delta Function

2.5.1 A Mathematical Anomaly

Consider the following vector function:

v ‚Üí = 1 r 2 r ^

At every location, v ‚Üí is directed radially outward which we can see in Fig. 2.11 . Let‚Äôs calculate its divergence:

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí = 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( r 2 1 r 2 ) = 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( 1 ) = 0

This is interesting as this calculation gives us an unforeseen solution. Let‚Äôs look at it closer. Suppose we integrate over a sphere of radius R , centred at the origin. The surface integral therefore is

‚àÆ v ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí = ‚à´ ( 1 R 2 r ^ ) ‚ãÖ ( R 2 sin ‚Å° ùúÉ d ùúÉ d œï r ^ ) = ( ‚à´ 0 œÄ sin ‚Å° ùúÉ d ùúÉ ) ( ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ d œï ) = 4 œÄ

But the volume integral ( ‚à´ ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí d œÑ ), should be zero (0) if we assume the aforementioned calculation to be true.

Does this mean that the divergence theorem is false?

The source of the problem lies at the point r = 0 , where v ‚Üí blows up . It is true that ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí = 0 everywhere except the origin, but right at the origin is the situation gets a little bit complicated.

Observe, the surface integral is independent of R . If the divergence theorem is to be true, we should expect

‚à´ ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí d œÑ = 4 œÄ ,

for any non-zero vector and the origin.

This means the value of 4 œÄ must be coming from the point r = 0 . Therefore, ‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ v ‚Üí has the unique property that it vanishes everywhere except at one point, and yet its integral is 4 œÄ .

No normal function behaves like that.

Information : An Analogy with Density

To wrap our heads around this property think of density .

The density of a point particle is zero except at the exact location of the particle, and yet its integral is finite. Namely, the mass of the particle.

What we have stumbled upon is called the Dirac delta function . It arises in numerous branches of theoretical physics and plays a central role in the theory of electrodynamics.

2.5.2 The 1D Dirac Delta Function

The one-dimensional Dirac delta function ( Œ¥ ( x ) ), can be pictured as an infinitely high, infinitesimally narrow ‚Äúspike‚Äù, with area 1.

That is to say:

Œ¥ ( x ) = { 0 , if x ‚â† 0 ‚àû , if x = 0

and,

‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû Œ¥ ( x ) d x = 1

In a strict sense of definition, Œ¥ ( x ) is NOT a function at all, as its value is not finite at x = 0 . In literature it is known as a generalised function. 22

If f ( x ) is some ‚Äúordinary‚Äù function, then the product ( f ( x ) Œ¥ ( x ) ) is zero everywhere except at x = 0 . It follows that:

f ( x ) Œ¥ ( x ) = f ( 0 ) Œ¥ ( x ) . (2.11)

The product is zero anyway except at x = 0 . Based on this property, we may as well replace f ( x ) by the value it assumes at the origin.

Particularly

‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû f ( x ) Œ¥ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû Œ¥ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) . (2.12)

Under an integral, then, the delta function ‚Äúpicks out‚Äù the value of f ( x ) at x = 0 . 23 Of course, we can shift the spike from x = 0 to some other point, x = a :

Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) = { 0 , if x ‚â† a ‚àû , if x = a with ‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) d x = 1 . (2.13)

which turns Eq. (2.11) into:

f ( x ) Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) = f ( a ) Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) , (2.14)

and Eq. (2.12) generalises to:

‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû f ( x ) Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) d x = f ( a ) . (2.15)

While Œ¥ itself is not a proper function, integrals over Œ¥ are perfectly acceptable. In fact, it‚Äôs best to think of the delta function as something that is always intended for use under an integral sign. In particular, two expressions involving delta functions. say D 1 ( x ) and D 2 ( x ) , are considered equal if:

‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû f ( x ) D 1 ( x ) d x = ‚à´ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû f ( x ) D 2 ( x ) d x , (2.16)

for all ordinary functions f ( x ) .

Exercise 2.26: A Simple Dirac Integral

Evaluate the following integral:

‚à´ 0 3 x 3 Œ¥ ( x ‚àí 2 ) d x

Solution

The delta function picks out the value of x 3 at the point x = 2 , so the integral is 2 3 = 8 . Notice, however, that if the upper limit had been 1 (instead of 3), the answer would be 0, because the spike would then be outside the domain of integration.

2.5.3 The 3D Dirac Delta Function

Once we have defined the 1D Dirac, it is simple to generalise it to 3D with the following:

Œ¥ 3 ( r ‚Üí ) = Œ¥ ( x ) Œ¥ ( y ) Œ¥ ( z ) , (2.21)

As we can see, it similar to 1D, where 3D Dirac is zero everywhere except at ( 0 , 0 , 0 ) , where it blows up. Its volume integral is 1:

‚à´ all¬†space Œ¥ 3 ( r ‚Üí ) d œÑ = ‚à≠ ‚àí ‚àû ‚àû Œ¥ ( x ) Œ¥ ( y ) Œ¥ ( z ) d x d y d z = 1

And, the general form is:

‚à´ all¬†space f ( r ‚Üí ) Œ¥ 3 ( r ‚Üí ‚àí a ‚Üí ) d œÑ = f ( a ‚Üí ) . (2.22)

As in the 1D case, integration with Œ¥ picks out the value of the function f at the location of the spike.

We can fix the paradox introduced in Section 2.5 . Remember, the divergence of r ^ ‚àï r 2 is zero everywhere except at the origin, however, its integral over any volume containing the origin is a constant.

These are precisely the defining conditions for the Dirac delta function; evidently

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( r ^ r 2 ) = 4 œÄ Œ¥ 3 ( r ‚Üí )

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ ( r ^ r 2 ) = 4 œÄ Œ¥ 3 ( r ^ ) (2.23)

2.6 Vector Field Theory

2.6.1 Helmholtz Theorem

Electricity and magnetism are generally expressed as electric and magnetic fields , E ‚Üí and B ‚Üí and like many physical laws, these are most compactly expressed as differential equations .

As E ‚Üí and B ‚Üí are vectors , the differential equations naturally involve vector derivatives: divergence and curl . Maxwell reduced the entire theory to four (4) fundamental equations, specifying respectively the divergence and the curl of E ‚Üí and B ‚Üí .

This formulation raises an interesting question:

To what extent is a vector function determined by its divergence and curl?

To study this case lets assume a vector of F ‚Üí . If the divergence of F ‚Üí is a specified scalar function D ,

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ F ‚Üí = D ,

and the curl of F ‚Üí is a specified vector function C ‚Üí ,

‚àá ‚Å° √ó F ‚Üí = C ‚Üí ,

and for consistency, we assume C ‚Üí to have NO divergence,

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ C ‚Üí = 0 ,

Remember, the divergence of a curl is ALWAYS zero.

Using this knowledge, is it possible to determine the function F ‚Üí ?

Without knowing more information, it is not really possible. There are many functions whose divergence and curl are both zero everywhere.

Some examples are:

F ‚Üí = 0 , F ‚Üí = ( y ) x ^ + ( z x ) ≈∑ + ( x y ) ·∫ë , F ‚Üí = ( sin ‚Å° x cosh ‚Å° y ) x ^ + ( ‚àí cos ‚Å° x sinh ‚Å° y ) ≈∑ + ( . ) ·∫ë

If we recall Higher Mathematics I , to solve a differential equation with a particular solution, we must also be supplied with appropriate boundary conditions .

In electrodynamics we typically require the fields go to zero at infinity. With that extra information, the Helmholtz theorem 24 guarantees the field is uniquely determined by its divergence and curl.

2.6.2 Potentials

If the curl of a vector field ( F ‚Üí ) vanishes everywhere, then F ‚Üí can be written as the gradient of a scalar potential ( V ):

‚àá ‚Å° √ó F ‚Üí = 0 ‚ü∫ F ‚Üí = ‚àí ‚àá ‚Å° V

The minus sign is purely conventional.

That‚Äôs the essential idea of the following theorem:

Theory 2.12: Zero Curl Fields

The following conditions are equivalent .

i.
‚àá ‚Å° √ó F ‚Üí = 0 everywhere,
ii.
‚à´ a ‚Üí b ‚Üí F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí is independent of path, for any given end points,
iii.
‚àÆ ‚Å° F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d l ‚Üí = 0 for any closed loop,
iv.
F ‚Üí is the gradient of some scalar function: F ‚Üí = ‚àí ‚àá ‚Å° V .
The potential is NOT unique as any constant can be added to V , since this will not affect its gradient.

If the divergence of a vector field ( F ‚Üí ) vanishes everywhere, then F ‚Üí can be expressed as the curl of a vector potential ( A ‚Üí ):

Theory 2.14: Zero Divergence Fields

‚àá ‚Å° ‚ãÖ F ‚Üí = 0 everywhere.

f F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí is independent of surface, for any given boundary line.

f F ‚Üí ‚ãÖ d a ‚Üí = 0 for any closed surface.
